snippet: Unlike after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January, calls for solidarity with Muslims have been rare while even the left-wing government considers harsher security measures.
abstract: Dearth of appeals for solidarity with Muslims in France points up how nation's secular society is now leaning toward outright distrust and even hostility in wake of Paris terror attacks; government is challenged on far right by anti-immigrant National Front party.

byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER and LIZ ALDERMAN
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Nabih Bulos, Alissa J. Rubin, Elian Peltier and Aurelien Breeden.

lead_paragraph: Unlike after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January, calls for solidarity with Muslims have been rare while even the left-wing government considers harsher security measures.

headline.main: After Paris Attacks, a Darker Mood Toward Islam Emerges in France
headline.print_headline: Distrust, Even Fear, as Secular France Cools on Muslims
